title: My Girl and I
descriptions:
My Girl and I (2005) is a tender South Korean romantic drama that unfolds as a bittersweet first love story remembered from adulthood. It centers on Su-ho, a quiet, well-meaning high school student in a small coastal town, and Su-eun, a kind, bright classmate whose gentle presence gradually transforms his life. The film tracks their relationship from a hesitant beginning to a deep, heartfelt bond, all framed by nostalgia and the inevitability of loss.

As the story opens, Su-ho is portrayed as an ordinary teenager navigating school life among friends and typical adolescent rivalries. He is good-natured but somewhat reserved, overshadowed by more boisterous classmates. Su-eun, on the other hand, is warm and thoughtful, known for her intelligence and soft-spoken charm. The two are drawn together after a chance encounter that becomes the foundation of their bond: Su-ho, impulsive and sincere, throws himself into danger to help Su-eun during a moment of crisis near the shoreline. Whether it’s regarded as an act of bravery or simple compassion, that single moment sets their relationship in motion.

Su-ho and Su-eun quickly grow close, but their connection is marked not by grand dramatic gestures so much as by the intimacy of everyday moments. They walk home together, whisper hopes and secrets, and share the quiet joy of companionship. The film lingers on their small rituals: notes passed between classes, gentle teasing, and the thrill of first love that turns the familiar world radiant. Su-ho’s friends notice the change in him—he is more open, more alive—while Su-eun’s warmth begins to draw him out of his shell. They plan simple dates, visit scenic spots along the coast, and dream, as teenagers do, of futures that blend seamlessly with the sweetness of the present.

Yet their happiness is not immune to the complexities of youth. There are petty jealousies, misunderstandings, and the relentless scrutiny of school gossip. Su-ho is inexperienced with emotions this strong and sometimes fumbles, not always saying or doing the right thing. Su-eun, mature beyond her years, tries to steady him with patience. Their disagreements are minor and transient, resolved with apologies and gestures that feel monumental in their innocence: a heartfelt letter, an awkward confession, a promise to be more attentive. In these moments, the film sketches first love as both fragile and resilient, a delicate thread strengthened by honesty.

Underneath the blossoming romance, however, lies a shadow. Su-eun’s health begins to falter. She hides her illness at first, unwilling to burden Su-ho or turn their time together into a litany of worries. Subtle signs—fatigue, faintness, a lingering pallor—creep into their days. When the truth emerges, it does so quietly but devastatingly: Su-eun is seriously ill. The revelation reshapes their love story into a race against time, with the pair determined to gather as many luminous moments as possible. They continue their dates and shared rituals with a new intensity, savoring each laugh, each sunset, each soft-spoken promise. Su-ho becomes fiercely devoted to Su-eun’s comfort, remaining by her side through hospital visits, treatments, and the emotional turbulence that accompanies them.

The film’s emotional climax centers on a cherished dream the couple share: to visit a particular island off their coastal town, a place that symbolizes escape, purity, and a future they might have had. Su-ho, youthful and stubborn, insists on making the journey even as Su-eun’s condition worsens. Their trip, woven through with moments of wonder and pain, is both a celebration and a farewell. As they are finally together on the island, surrounded by light and sea, the story distills their love into a handful of quiet scenes: the brush of hands, a promise whispered into the wind, a sense that time is both too short and somehow infinite within the boundaries of their connection.

Ultimately, Su-eun’s illness claims her, and Su-ho is left to grapple with grief. The film doesn’t dwell on melodrama; instead, it shows how grief alters the textures of the everyday. Su-ho returns to familiar places now haunted by memory—the school corridors, the shoreline, the island that once felt like a threshold to the future. He carries with him the echoes of their days together, their plans, and the lessons she gave him: to be brave, to be kind, to love fully even when the cost is unbearable. His friends try to comfort him, but there is a loneliness to first love lost that can only be borne, not fixed.

The narrative frame suggests that Su-ho recounts this story as an adult, years later, when he has returned to the town or encountered some token of the past that reopens the chambers of memory. In revisiting his first love, he confronts the way time both erases and preserves. Objects carry weight—a scarf, a letter, a photograph
